Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 10:44AM lissyross wrote: So sorry to hear that SPAMgirl.  If there is one thing I've learned in the past couple of years, there are no guarantees with any of this stuff, you kind of have to go with your gut and hope for the best.  I'm not too hung up on the symetric thing, obviously I would want them to be as symetrical as possible (not that they are perfectly symetrical right now!), but I think its the significant recovery period, possibility of lymphodema, etc. that is really what is freaking me out right now.   Never a dull moment with this!
Posts.Title: New primary with different receptors...mastectomy vs. lumpectomy lissyross lissyross

Posts.Content: lissyross wrote: Hi everyone,  I was diagnosed with Stage IV invasive ductal BC about 2-1/2 years ago in my left breast, ER+/PR+, a single met in my left femor.  I was treated with tamoxifen and zometa initially, had a oopherectomy, and now I am treated with Femara and Xgeva.  I have been responding well, minimal side effects (typical bone pain/stiffness/hot flashes), and both the primary tumor and met have improved.  Now a month ago a second primary showed up in the same breast, but this one is ER+ weak, and PR-.  It is small, as I am scanned regularly, but there was some question as to how best to treat the new primary, since the hormone treatment I have been on will be no good for this one.  My oncologist suggested surgery as the best option, as this one has been caught so early that the hope is they can get rid of it completely.  I wouldn't need radiation or chemo.  If I wait, and this one spreads as well, then chemo would be my only option.  I am OK with the surgical option, but the surgeon I saw is recommending a full mastectomy, not just a lumpectomy for the new primary.  I'm trying to find information on this, whether it makes sense to do this, and whether it will be good/bad/no difference for my first tumor and mets.  I have seen some research that suggests that women who were diagnosed with Stage IV, have treatment that includes a mastectomy have better survival rates, but this is not what I was told (and most of you) when I was first diagnosed.  I have not found anyone else in this particular situation, so if anyone has been here before me, please let me know what was suggested to you, and how you went forward with treatment.  I am 43, in good physical shape, so I think I will be OK with a mastecomy if it is the best option, but I'm just trying to find out what others in my situation have done. Everything in this moment is as it should be. Dx 11/10/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New primary with different receptors...mastectomy vs. lumpectomy lissyross lissyross

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 07:52AM lissyross wrote: Thanks for your responses.  I am definitely leaning towards the mastectomy, especially given the fact that they think there are lymph nodes involved (I have an FNA for that tomorrow), and I agree that if there are now 2 there, the possibility is pretty strong that there is other small stuff floating around that doesn't show up on scan and mammos. My concern is that mx is a much bigger surgery, more recovery, etc. so I just want to make sure I am 100% on doing it.   Surgery is already scheduled for three weeks out, I'm at Sloan Kettering, so I'm very confident in the skill and knowledge of the doctors, but I need the reassurance from the "real people"  that are actually going thru this.  Great to have this forum to bounce these things off of others, it always helps to know you are all out there dealing with the same stuff.
Posts.Title: New primary with different receptors...mastectomy vs. lumpectomy lissyross lissyross

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 03:06PM - edited May 7, 2010 03:09PM by lissyross I am doing this as well, but my oncologist told me I should consider getting the ovaries removed, otherwise I have to keep getting the Lupron shots once a month.  I am trying to weigh the advantages and disadvantages to both, but haven't been able to find too much information. Is there any point in having them removed once you have been on Lupron for 2 years if you are in menopause anyway?  Do the ovaries still produce some estrogen after menopause, so removal is suggested?   I will get further details from my doc next time I see her, but any info you can provide would be appreciated.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 06:04AM lissyross wrote: Well, after discussing this with my oncologist and an ob/gyn surgeon, I have decided to have my ovaries removed.  I am pre-menopausal, been on tamoxifen for about 8 months and lupron for about 6 months.  My antigen levels really haven't decreased as my onc would have liked, the primary tumor hasn't gotten any smaller, and that is what made me decide to go forward with the ovary removal.  Both doctors told me that the lupron shots are not as effective in stopping estrogen production as the oopherectomy will be, and since I'm not concerned about fertility anymore, I felt this was the best route.  I have really had very few side effects from the drugs, but they are not working as well as we would like, so this is the next step.  As I have already hit menopause from the lupron, I'm not too concerned about that, I know it may have other effects, but I'll deal with that if it helps to reduce the tumor and keeps me going longer.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 08:46AM lissyross wrote: 40, almost 41.  Stage IV at presentation, as they say.  I had my first mammo at 35, which was fine, already had my appt to get the second one when my OB/GYN found the lump during an annual exam.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 01:56PM lissyross wrote: I felt my mets before I was even diagnosed, left femur that hurt while I was running.  Thought it was an injury, was diagnosed with bc a few days later, and the bone scan two weeks later revealed a spot exactly where my leg hurt, what a coincidence!! When my doctor told me what it probably was, I freaked a little, guess that is to be expected, no one wants to hear they have mets.    I still feel it almost every day, it is a very mild pain, but definitely noticeable.   Wish you all the best with your scans, and to everyone here, know that you are not alone, there are alot of us out here with you.  Keep your chin up!!
Posts.Title: stage IV breast to bone mets ejnova reesie

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 04:58PM lissyross wrote: Just an update for you all, I had an xray of my femur this week, and the Zometa is working well, only 4 months and the lesion is healing nicely.  I go next week for another CT and bone scan, as it has been 6 months already since the last ones, so fingers crossed that all goes well.
